metadata.title: The role of routine versus random movements on the spread of disease in Great Britain Supplementary Information 1 Census data and National Travel Survey

abstract.text: The latest census of the population of the United Kingdom was taken in 2001 where each household was required to fill in a census form providing details on each member. These data are aggregated at several spatil scales, with the postcode unit being the smallest area for which data are available. However, the range of census counts at this level is very limited. At the second level, Output Area, the data become unreliable due to small cell adjustment to protect anonymity. Furthermore, the number of Output Areas is 217,038 in Great Britain, which demands a high computational overhead for modelling purposes. The main body of the island of Great Britain forms a natural unit which we chose to model, and we chose to exclude Northern Ireland from the study. Taking all these factors into account, we chose to define our model at the level of census wards for England and Wales and CAS wards in Scotland(1; 2).

There is considerable heterogeneity in population density in Great Britain, with high density wards being concentrated around urban centres. These areas also contain the largest proportion of workers compared to the total population. Figure S1 shows how the population is distributed across the UK.

body_text.text: The latest census of the population of the United Kingdom was taken in 2001 where each household was required to fill in a census form providing details on each member. These data are aggregated at several spatil scales, with the postcode unit being the smallest area for which data are available. However, the range of census counts at this level is very limited. At the second level, Output Area, the data become unreliable due to small cell adjustment to protect anonymity. Furthermore, the number of Output Areas is 217,038 in Great Britain, which demands a high computational overhead for modelling purposes. The main body of the island of Great Britain forms a natural unit which we chose to model, and we chose to exclude Northern Ireland from the study. Taking all these factors into account, we chose to define our model at the level of census wards for England and Wales and CAS wards in Scotland(1; 2).
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: There is considerable heterogeneity in population density in Great Britain, with high density wards being concentrated around urban centres. These areas also contain the largest proportion of workers compared to the total population. Figure S1 shows how the population is distributed across the UK. These data give us the total number of individuals per ward, N i , directly.
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: Since the 1991 census, each individual in a household was asked to specify their work location as well as their home address. In order to protect anonymity the 1991 census reported a 10% sample of the complete data, whereas the 2001 data was released in its entirety but with small cell adjustments. Census data also contain work locations and home locations of the working population(3; 4).
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: The National Travel Survey (NTS) is a continuous survey on personal travel, which samples 5,796 private addresses in Great Britain (5) . Each individual in each household keeps a 7 day travel diary detailing each journey made. Figure S2a shows the distribution of distances travelled classified by the purpose of the journey. On the same figure we show the same distribution as extracted from the census data for the working population. The data are not identical, but the general patterns closely follow each other. Very short journeys (less than 1km) are the least frequent journeys made, and the most common journeys are in the range of 10-15 km, both for work and for other purposes. Weekend journeys show a more pronounced tail of the distribution, implying that people are more inclined to make long journeys at the weekend. The effect of assuming that non-workers move according to two different distributions: the grey curve shows the epidemic profile for the reduced model, using the Census data to parameterise both worker and non-worker movements; the black curve shows the epidemic profile for the full model, using the Census data to parameterise worker movements, but using the National Travel Survey to parameterise non-worker movements. We parameterise our model with these two data sets in the following way:
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: Commuters: Patches i and j are coupled by the number of commuters known to travel from i to j for work, denoted W i j . This is taken directly from the census.
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: Non-workers:Non-commuters are given a probability of moving from i to j on each day, denoted P i j . We define P i j initially to be W i j / j W i j . This is further weighted by the discrepancy between work and non-work related movements from the National Travel Survey.
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: The distribution of distances travelled can have an effect on the progression of the epidemic in our model (see figure 3 b ). Although the final epidemic size remains the same, using the distribution of distances travelled extracted from the National Travel Survey makes for an epidemic that is shorter and more acute.
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: The value of the length of day parameter δ in the model has an impact on the dynamics of spread. For simplicity, we chose δ to be the same for workers and non-workers. For large values of δ individuals spend most of their time within their home ward leading to a slow spread of disease. As this value is increased and individuals spend more time outside of their home patch, the speed and magnitude of spread is increased. This is due to increased dispersal associated mostly with random movers; workers spend all of their time in either their home patch or their work patch, but random movers may spend some time in many patches that are not their home patch. Should the total amount of time spent away from home be high, the effective coupling between patches is increased due to the presence of random movers.
body_text.section: Census data and National Travel Survey

body_text.text: The disease transmission parameters used in our models were obtained from the literature. In the case of smallpox, we used the latest estimates from the recent smallpox review paper (6) . For smallpox a newly infected individual passes through three classes corresponding to the incubation period which lasts on average 12 days and during which the individual is infected but not infectious. This is followed by a prodromal period during which the individual is mildly infectious and which lasts on average 3 days. An acute infectious period follows, lasting on average 4 days followed by a prolonged period of mild infectiousness associated with isolation, after which the individual stops being infectious due to recovery or death.

In the case of influenza we use estimates from two different sources (7; 8) used in (9) , and tailor them to our modelling framework. Influenza is characterised by a short incubation period of 1-2 days followed by 3-4 days of infectiousness, after which the individuals recover for the most part. The incidence of severe symptoms (and death) is assumed to be extremely low, so we do not model these explicitly.
The values of β c and γ c used are given in Table 1 .

FIGREF1.text: (a) Epidemic curves for a range of values of length of day, δ (b) The speed of initial spread as a function of δ. As the amount of time individuals spend in their home wards increases, the speed and magnitude of the epidemic is reduced.
